WOODROSE.

This is news to me.

iceable differences (j.n.d.) in impact. Calculations for the tobac

result.ocr_text:
The overall objective for the Corporation's domestic marketing
group will be to stop the erosion of the Company's market share
and reestablish itself in the tobacco industry as a strong and
viable competitor by stabilizing established brands' share of
segment and developing and marketing new products in the mainstream,
non-menthol category. To this end, the group's first priority
will be to launch BARcLAy nationally, assuming satisfactory test
market performance. Additional new product work will continue on
foom other alterabit new product opportunities recognizing both
current ultra low tar poesibilities as well as new opportunities
which may occur as a consequence of external/environmental changes.
Giving first priority to the launch of a new brand in no way signals
an intent to abandon an aggressive posture with respect to efforts
to minimize the erosion in volume on established brands. KOOL,
in particular, will be managed with heavy marketing resources
focusing on stabilizing the parent in its category and on finding
…
the competitive edge that will give the low tar styles greater
growth potential. The overall objective for the Corporation's
established brands is to produce budgeted or better volume within
corporate spending and profit guidelines. In addition, the brands
must pursue an aggressive testing program to demonstrate opportunities
for investing incremental funds in order to build total share of
market.

BROWN & WILLIAMSON TOBACCO CORPORATION
RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT

FILE NOTE
SUBJECT:
PAPER RECON FROM MARLBORO KS AND MARLBORO MENTHOL LIGHTS
100'S/451
AUTHOR:
E. D. Alford

DATE:
November 20, 1987
CC:
M. L. Reynoids, T. F. Riehl, C. N. Kounnas, A. McMurtrie,
D. V. Cantrell. J. H. Lauterbach,.J. F. Nall, W. H. Deines,
R. R. Johnson, E. F. Litzinger, D. A. Colby, W. R. Conway,
R. H. Marshall
?
SUMMARY
2
The paper recons from Marlboro KS and Marlboro Menthol Lights loo's
were found to be different. The paper recon from Marlboro KS
contained DAP and therefore exhibited the sugar-armonia products. The
Marlboro Menthol Lights loo's paper recon did not contain phosphate in
excess of the level typically found in PJS where no DAP was added.
Therefore, the levels of the sugar-anmonia prggucts were much lower
(80-8s%) in the paper recon from Marlboro Menthol Lights 1oo's.
It has not been proven, but the furnish for the two paper recon are
also thought to be different. The furnish for the paper recon found
in Marlboro KS was thought to be heavily skewed toward burley while,
the furnish for the Marlboro Menthol Ligbts loo's was thought to be
skewed toward flue-cured furnish.
A comparison of the paper and dark recons from Marlboro Ks were also
made. This comparison showed that paper recon exhibited most of the
sugar-ammonia reaction products found in the dark recon and in about
the same quantities. The major differences were found in the welatile
alkyl pyrazines region of the PaT profiles.
INTRODUCTION
2
Bob Jobnson bad isolated the paper recon from Marlboro KS and Mariboro
Menthol Ligbts loo's. These materials, along with the dark recon from
Marlboro KS, were eramined by purge-and-trap (PaT) and direct
R
silylation (DS) GC-Ms. The combination of both of these analyues
shoved the volatiles from the alkylpyrazines to deoxyfructosazine and
fructosaziues. Data from both of the analyses were ueed to reach the
s
conclusions drawm in this file note.
*

IV.
INITIATING VERSUS DEVELOPMENTAL INFLUENCES
eneral Comments
It is obviously aifficult to separate influences on the initiati
f cardiovascular diseases and those which affect the development of such
liseases once they are established.
This is especially true where recognition and classification of
lisease occur only after other symptoms exist, as is usually the case.
As might be expected, there is no hard and fast rule or universi
onsistent clinical opinion on this matter. It is ciear that individuals
iffer in response to smoking and to their deprivation from the habit.
Further research may conceivably indicate that a sufficiently h:
ercentage of those with established degrees of cardiovascular disorders 1
eact so unfavorably to smoking as to justify medical advice on certain c
f restrictive action. This, however, is properly a matter of relationsh:
etween the individual doctor and his patient. The desired situation is 
hich will involve es broad and comprehensive knowledge as can possibly b
equired to guide the profession in the light of its clinical experience.
The references appended will present opinions which are based or
ich experience. They should be considered as being contributory rather t
onclusive and as being selected for purposes of comparison.
The important point is that more refined and sophisticated
ongitudinal studies of controlled populations of apparently normal indivi
rom normalcy which represent the earliest evidence of the diseases under
cudy and which, therefore, may be closely connected with their origin.
Similarly, manipulable populations of patients with established
rly cardiovascular diseases should provide material for more sophisticat
inical studies of factors which may influence the progress and course of
lese diseases.
Until such studies are organized and bear fruit we shall have to
content with a type of evidence which leaves doubt as to whether we are
aling with factors which influence origin alone, progressive development
one, or both.
